thread.title: Top NASCAR drivers face tough odds at Talladega
thread.title_full: Top NASCAR drivers face tough odds at Talladega

title: Top NASCAR drivers face tough odds at Talladega
text:
Four of the 12 drivers left in the Chase for the NASCAR Sprint Cup Championship will join the ranks of also rans after Sunday’s CampingWorld.com 500 at Talladega Superspeedway. 
The most likely candidates facing elimination are Matt Kenseth, Dale Earnhardt Jr., Ryan Newman and Kyle Busch. 
Kenseth is in the most dire straights having to overcome a 35-point deficit between his No. 20 Joe Gibbs Racing Toyota and the No. 78 Furniture Row Chevrolet team of Martin Truex Jr. who holds down the eighth and final cut-off Chase position. 
Earnhardt sits 31 points back of Truex in the No. 88 Hendrick Motorsports Chevrolet, with Newman eight back in the No. 31 Richard Childress Racing Chevrolet and Busch six points back in the No. 18 JGR Toyota. 
The fight for the eight spots that will advance to the next Chase round is exacerbated by the fact Joey Logano won both of the first two races of the current round in the No. 22 Team Penske Racing Ford, making him the only driver with a free pass to Martinsville next week. 
Of course, those four are not the only ones in danger of being squeezed from contention. 
Jeff Gordon, in the No. 24 Chevrolet, Kevin Harvick in the No. 4 Chevrolet and Brad Keselowski in the No. 2 Ford are only one point in front of Truex and one wreck involving any of them would probably end their Chase dreams. 
It is all, of course, a by-product of restrictor-plate racing at Talladega where packs of cars racing at or near 200 mph are inches apart where even a minor miscue can create a major disaster. 
“That’s just the biggest crap shoot we have,” Kyle Busch said of Talladega racing. “If we can make it through this round then to me the rest of the year is kind of simple.” 
Earnhardt, who has had the most recent success at the 2.66-mile banked oval, said he will have to be at the top of his game if he wants to move to the next round but he feels he has the car to do it on Sunday. 
“When you feel like you have a dominant car like we’ve had over the last several years, you definitely make some moves with confidence and you come into the race with confidence,” he said. “Until we see anything different, we’ll be confident.” 
Unlike other drivers in his must-win situation, Earnhardt said he enjoys the pressure and the desperate racing it produces. 
“There’s no denying the intensity and the pressure it puts on drivers like myself to be in a cutoff situation where you’re eliminated if things don’t go perfectly on Sunday,” he said. “But I think it’s what the fans enjoy. 
“Even if we don’t make it through this weekend, I think it’s still going to be exciting. It was great last year even when we weren’t a part of it. It was amazing to watch.” 
For four-time champion Gordon, it is his last kick at the can as he retires at the end of this season and he said it will pretty much be all out all the time on Sunday for him. 
“You have to be a little more aggressive (at Talladega),” he said. “I watched Dale Jr., and a few other guys who protect their position when they’re up front aggressively. 
“But I can tell you that it’s a lot harder than it used to be; people are smarter, cars are more equal, and the draft and aerodynamics are different than they used to be.” 
Gordon did get a leg up on the competition, winning the pole on a lap of 194.500 mph. 
Kenseth said there are any number of things that will affect the outcome of the race and he views it as a giant chess game where a move early in the race can make a difference late in the race. 
“It’s all about being in the right place and being positioned properly and not making just the right moves for yourself, but yet the moves that the rest of the cars make too and certainly being a race in the Chase everybody’s kind of on a different agenda or some people are locked in and are just going to help their teammates — there’s all kinds of different scenarios,” he said. 
Newman, who last year made it through to the final Chase race at Homestead without ever winning a race, sees three scenarios in his quest to repeat that feat. 
“You can have a strategy where you know you have a car that can stay up front, you can think you have a car that can stay up front, stay in the middle all day and race and get crashed or cause a crash, or you can watch everybody from the back and try and learn and go at the end,” he said. 
CANUCK HAYLEY COMES UP BIG 
When the 2015 NASCAR Camping World Truck Series season started back at Daytona International Speedway, rookie Cameron Hayley said he was apprehensive about racing on the big superspeedways, tracks that were totally new to the 19-year-old Calgary native. 
On Saturday, he steered his way through a series of late-race wrecks to bring home the No. 13 ThorSports Racing Toyota sixth — his best big-track finish of the season at Talladega Superspeedway. 
“I’m starting to like these two-and-a-half mile tracks,” Hayley said after getting out of his truck. 
And so he should because when the checkered flag ended the race only about a third of the 32 cars that started the Fred’s 250 finished without some sort of damage. 
“We were up and down all day,” Hayley said of the race won by Timothy Peters. “I mean I am happy, we avoided all the wrecks.” 
He was running eighth when the final caution came out after a massive wreck that took out 10 trucks. 
“I think we could have had a top-five (finish) but we had to restsart on the outside lane which was not the preferred line,” Hayley said. 
Now it’s off to the tiny half-mile Martinsville Speedway oval next week, something he is looking forward to. 
“It’s the kind of track I grew up racing on,” Hayley said. Sponsored Links
